message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which is confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound. The next step in management is an air contrast enema, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. Supportive care alone is not enough, an abdominal CT scan may be useful for certain complications but not necessary as a next step, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of blood in the stool suggest intussusception as the diagnosis. An air contrast enema is the preferred method for diagnosis and treatment of intussusception in young children. Supportive care may be necessary, but the enema should be the first step. Abdominal CT scan and broad-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which can be diagnosed by abdominal ultrasound. The next step in management is an air contrast enema. Supportive care may not be enough, and antibiotics or CT scan are not standard of care for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, which can be confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound. The best next step in management would be an air contrast enema, which can also be diagnostic and potentially therapeutic. Supportive care may not address the underlying issue. Abdominal CT scan may be unnecessary, and broad-spectrum antibiotics would not be indicated for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the diagnosis of intussusception, and an air contrast enema is the appropriate next step in management to both diagnose and treat the condition. Supportive care may be appropriate in less severe cases, but the presence of bloody stools suggests a more urgent intervention. Abdominal CT scan may provide additional information but is not the next step in management. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest intussusception, which is a medical emergency. Air contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic, and is the recommended next step in management. Supportive care alone is not enough, and antibiotics are not indicated unless there is evidence of infection. Abdominal CT scan may be useful, but is not the first-line diagnostic test for intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of periodic episodes of abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool suggests intussusception. Air contrast enema is the diagnostic and therapeutic tool of choice for intussusception. Supportive care can be given while preparing for the procedure, but antibiotics and CT scan are not indicated for this condition.

The symptoms suggest that the baby has intussusception, which is confirmed by the abdominal ultrasound. The next step in management would be an air contrast enema to help reduce the intussusception. Supportive care could be an option if the intussusception is resolved, but if it persists, further intervention would be necessary. An abdominal CT scan and broad-spectrum antibiotics are not appropriate for the management of intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intussusception, and an air contrast enema can both diagnose and treat this condition. Supportive care can be given during the procedure, but without treatment, the condition can become life-threatening. Abdominal CT Scan and Broad-spectrum antibiotics are not necessary for the diagnosis and treatment of intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, periodic episodes of abdominal pain and blood in the diaper, suggest intussusception. Air contrast enema is the initial management for diagnosis and reduction of intussusception in children. Supportive care may help with symptoms but does not treat the underlying condition. Abdominal CT scan and broad-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated for intussusception.
